SENT.plain: Twenty-nine cases of infantile cortical hyperostosis with a wide range of bone involvement are reviewed
Soft tissue painful swellings began before roentgenographic changes appeared in the underlying bone
In 17 babies gradual involvement of different bones was noted
In seven cases lesions previously healed became reactivated
The disease is self-limiting and appears in a narrow age group
The clinical picture and laboratory data are reported
Differential diagnosis and possible etiological factors are discussed
The similarity of infantile cortical hyperostosis to extreme periosteal new bone formation in response to trauma in sensorily deprived children is suggested as a possible etiological factor
